title: Chord: Dominant 7#5 in G (Shape: G)

# Dominant 7#5 Chord in G

The Dominant 7#5 chord in G is a spicy and dissonant chord that adds tension and a jazzy flavor to your music. It consists of the notes G, B, D#, and F. This chord is also known as the augmented seventh chord due to its augmented fifth (or sharp fifth) and dominant seventh intervals.

## Notes and Intervals Breakdown:
- G (Root)
- B (Major Third)
- D# (Sharp Fifth)
- F (Dominant Seventh)

## Musical Flavor and Usage:
The Dominant 7#5 chord is often used in jazz and fusion genres to create tension and add a modern, edgy sound to chord progressions. It has a dissonant quality that can resolve in interesting ways, making it a popular choice for adding harmonic color and complexity to compositions.

## Examples in Songs:
Here are three songs that feature the Dominant 7#5 chord in G:
1. "So What" by Miles Davis
2. "Spain" by Chick Corea
3. "All Blues" by Miles Davis

These songs showcase how the Dominant 7#5 chord can be used creatively in different musical contexts to enhance the overall sound and harmonic structure.
